review_title: only if you want a secure job with mediocre pay
pros: great place to work. No micromanage. the facility is well maintained, cleaned, and secured. great benefits. gym is awesome and super cheap,like 3 dollars a month.
cons: the pay is not the greatest. I come from a sales backround where those commissions motivate you to perform to the best of your abilities. At humana, there is no such thing as extra pay. no commissions no, no bonus, no overtime.

job_title: Social Service Care Manager in Tampa, FL
pros: Pays well. Great 401k matching. WAH, so no commute.
cons: Humana at Home: Micro Managed to the point of mental health issues for most member facing employees. Work life balance is terrible. Lack of concern about associate wellness from upper management. Health benefits are pretty terrible.

pros: Cares about employee satisfaction and engagement (because it matters to the Street), great benefits package, smart colleagues, ability to move around in the company to different business segments, decent compensation, people are genuine and believe in the values and mission of the company
cons: Too much deference to management, salaries not transparent, roles lack clarity/titles don't fit role responsibilities, so big that building momentum and keeping it can be challenging

pros: Nice people and at times a fun work environment.  There is usually unlimited overtime during AEP, which can make for a lucrative season.
cons: There is no continuity.  Protocol changes on what appears to be practically a daily basis.  There is very little room for advancement and raises are usually non-existent.  Management is terrible and you are treated like a number, not a person.  Please do yourself a favor, in that is you are interested in selling insurance, go to any other company than this one!

job_title: RN Field Care Manager in Bloomington, MN
pros: Humana invests in their employees. They really value and encourage health and wellness, along with work/life balance.
cons: The company was laying off at the time I left, which caused insecurity. There were too many changes all at once- salaried employees changed to hourly, reduced mileage reimbursement, increased required territory coverage. I lost my manager and most of my team, and I was then transferred to another state's manager/team.

job_title: HR4U Call Center Representative in Louisville, KY
pros: Great benefits like tuition reimbursement 4 to 5 weeks of vacation a year good health insurance and pay.
cons: Metrics are very hard to meet the department was sometimes very unorganized, employees don’t really see us as coworkers but as a customer service sometime they get little disrespectful with us.  Oh and asking for PTO is so hard they rarely approve you because they are under staff

review_title: A HMO that allows it's employees to pay high premiums.
pros: A pay check and good people to work with.
cons:
No Good health benefits are give to employees.  If you are single with a child or children, the best benefit they have to offer is $300 a month in premium, $30-$40 copay and $3500 deductable before any claims is paid.  They have absolutely no respect for their employees. 
Management don't care.  They are there physically to get their big checks and bonuses..

job_title: Registered Nurse in Ormond Beach, FL
pros: work at home and 4  ten hour day week option
cons: health insurance plan is high deductible- cutting other benefits and raising premiums/deductible level without giving anyone in our dept a raise- regardless of evaluation/performance

pros: The best reason to work here is the pay is much higher than the average Joe can get anywhere else in Louisville
cons: Management in my area is incompetent.  Wait til last minute to do important things, hire the wrong people for the job, play favorites (golf buddies are promoted rather than those with actual talent)

pros:
$24k Base Salary plus very good commissions
Excellent Training for new agents
HIgh quality sales leads provided by company 
High level of integrity and knowledge among field employees 
Very competitive Medicare Advantage product
cons:
Medicare sales  peak from October thru early December, very high work load
Intimidating emphasis on detailed compliance requirements
Non Medicare insurance products are less than stellar

review_title: Work at home RN care manager
job_title: RN Care Manager in Cincinnati, OH
pros:
Work life balance
Great pay 
Welcoming atmosphere 
I have a fantastic manager! 
Very health conscious company
Very positive. Not a lot of focusing on the negative. They focus on what you're doing well.
cons:
Can be hard depending on your manager (coach). Mine is very supportive but I know not everyone has that luxury. 
Feeling like a salesperson trying to keep people in the care management program

review_title: Not a bad place to work.
pros: Usually decent working conditions/environment.  The pay is mostly competitive.
cons: Having to constantly drink the latest organizational kool-aid/propaganda and industry fads.  Some departments are cold and siloed.  A few are able to create working team "families".  There is a LOT of politics.  This is a huge organization that is built on bureaucracy.

pros: Great Benefits, Employees engaged, steady work, plenty of overtime. Excellent training and thorough explanations. Worked Medicare: Billing, Enrollment, Pharmacy, Agent Line and Claims.
cons: Training is great but with larger classes it can become a little stuffy. I don't really have anything negative to say about this company. I loved working for them.

review_title: Great Corporate Benefits, Very Poor Cultural Environment
pros: Benefits, paid time off, paid volunteer time off, gas reimbursement, recognition for accomplishments
cons: My position was treated very poorly by many in the office, even to the point of bullying. Management stood by and did little to restore positive environment, despite this person being reported multiple times by several different people. Even some unethical practices with upper level management and personal relations with lower level-employees.

pros: High pay, overtime available,  plenty of room for growth within the company.
cons: Benefits are expensive, managers are rude, training appears to be thorough but it is not, during peak season you have mandatory overtime which is okay but it's not ok that you are unaware of until the day of. The managers are very degrading and power hungry. As well as disrespectful. I complained to ethics in regards to a manager and was fired the next day. I've heard this happen several times.

pros:
Pay is good.
Benifits aren't that great. High deductable. 
Enjoy the people I work with.
cons:
SIU's new management are not approachable.
They only hire people from outside of Humana.
Micro manage the investigators so they can't make decissions for themselves.
Several of the WAH investigators don't even work most of the day. Complaints have been provided to management. Nothing done.
SIU researchers are not appriciated or utilized. 
No incentives or bonues.

pros: Can build good relationships with guests and employees; a rewarding role when you see changes people make based on information they learned from you.
cons: Lots of new ideas are brought up but frequently fall in the cracks.  Pay raises were few and far between.

review_title: Not a good company to work for ! Poor management overworked and underpaid employees!
job_title: Inbound Contact Representative in Irving, TX
pros: Option to work at home
cons: They do not care about Employee’s well-being . They are always adding more training and more skills and adding more pilots and will not give you a raise. They have frequent shift bids and they do not allow time for life changes.  They only care about your numbers and what you can do for the business and not how happy you are as an employee. The workload is stressful and they can care less how their employees feel they only care about how many members you serve and the quality of your surveys.

pros: Good tools and infrastructure.
cons: Concerning ethical behaviors amongst leadership.  I would only consider working outside of the call centers if I were a white male from a traditional American background and really well connected in the Louisville area.  The culture of the company is to cut corners and fudge numbers. It's a true old boys network.  Most of the leadership is rewarded for making decisions that align with their personal/individual interests as opposed to the good of the company.  If you have other options, go there.

pros: Whether working for their call centers or their warehouses, Humana pays above average for entry-level positions. A great place to start working. They also give a generous amount of PTO for full time employees.
cons: On the flip side, they tend to pay a little less for higher, more specialized positions. Once you have some work experience under you're belt, or if you're already experienced and looking to make a move, there may be better options.

review_title: I've had amazing leaders here over the years who really care about me and my well-being. The flexibility is world-class!
job_title: Project Manager in Meadow Vale, KY
pros: The flexibility is amazing, I can work from home as much as I want to, and my team really cares about me as a person. There are so many development opportunities and Humana offers a very generous tuition reimbursement program.
cons: Moving up in the company is tough and it's also challenging knowing what each role's pay band is, as this information is not published anywhere.

job_title: Social Services Coordinator in Orlando, FL
pros: Great direct Supervisor, works with you and is always open/honest. Will fight for you and has the teams best interest in mind.
cons: Not easy to build your career. I have applied for several positions and would love to stay/grow with the company but it is who you know and not based on experience or what you can bring to the role.

review_title: It has been very challenging having to prove my title as an Experience Customer Service Agent
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tucson, AZ
pros: Flexible hours, working along side other's, gaining member's trust, giving the upmost all that is pleased for the work that is presented at Humama
cons: Straying ahead of the trainings, being part of the company, getting upper management to be fair all around not only when they feel it's convenient

review_title: Consistently disappointing regarding upward mobility and leadership.
pros: Ability to earn a moderate income.
cons: Very little upward mobility.  The business "silos" are still alive and well within the Humana culture.  Little concern for members well-being despite their visual efforts to appear member-centric.  Obvious cross department symbiosis is ignored or quashed.

pros: the money that they pay us is great. they start you out really well. The hours are very flexible. Down here in louisville you get to choose 8 house each day from the hours of 7am-7pm
cons: its not enough vacation time. I wish the desk were alil bigger. I wish that we could do more volenteer things outside the building.

pros: Decent pay,, other areas may be better like  Florida and Louisville so I do know satisfaction better in other regions,  nice corporate communications.  Humana vitality nice
cons: Terrible insurance, revolving door, poor managers, don't care about workers, actually lie and bully, worst people performance get promoted.  If you want to have an ulcer and be thrown under bus then this is your place!!

pros: I cant think of any
cons: They want to have their employees make more bricks with less straw. Management is clueless what things are functioning at the "lower level".Very impatient and unrealistic management..They make choices that benefits upper management but not the people in the trenchs that work for them.They promise alot but dont deliver.

pros: This is a great company that has many upward paths. You are not limited if you work hard. In my experience, management wants you to be able to have a great work-life balance.
cons: Some business partners appear to compete rather than assist. I have never had this problem, but some managers apparently don't want you to take time off if you are sick.

review_title: Good and bad depending on who you work for.
pros: Good co-workers, PTO is ok - they do not differentiate between new hires with no experience versus new hires with a lot of experience.
cons: I have had good bosses and bad bosses.  The problem with the bad ones is they are usually pre-occupied with other things and you are left twisting in the wind.  I do not trust the people I work for currently.

review_title: From a software development perspective, Humana has significant technical debt and self-imposed regulatory impediments.
pros:
Deep pockets and strong growth
Caring, progressive atmosphere
Strong leadership
cons:
Innovation at Humana is next to impossible, due to backwards security policies
Everything IT related moves very slowly
The health benefits are not right for everyone, they are high-deductible plans which are not well understood by providers in the Boston area

pros: Working from home and benefits
cons: Management not in line with company mission or vision. No team work is possible as there is plain favoritism and no balance of responsibilities between teams. Supervisors have an attitude of superiority and lack of concern, interviews for open positions are conducted with a lack of respect, asking for requirements they don't meet.

job_title: Medical Record Retrieval Specialist in Knoxville, TN
pros: The benefits were excellent. You also started accumulating PTO hours from the first day. I also was not micro-managed, so that made it more enjoyable.
cons: It was a bit stressful with the deadlines for various reviews. However, it got better over the years. It also wasn't fun finding out about the Aetna merger via email over the 4th of July weekend.

review_title: Humana is a great organization to work for
pros: Diverse culture, flexible work schedule, encouraged to develop self and pursue growth opportunities. Organization is very focused on leadership and analytics.
cons: Organization seems a bit unorganized at times. Work is reactive instead of proactive many times, part of that is due to the nature of healthcare.

pros: Good place to work.  Like the fact that this corporation is a good corporate citizen in the community.  There are an abundance of opportunities.  Work at home options,
cons: Company is in the process of getting acquired so there is an uncertain future for the company.  Lots of long term management.

review_title: Depends on your department and leaders
pros: Excellent retirement matching and other benefits
cons: There are major differences between departments as far as culture and work/life balance. I got lucky to land in an excellent environment, but I know a lot of people who weren't so lucky.

job_title: Hospital Contract Executive in Atlanta, GA
pros: Work At Home May be available, 401k match, PTO
cons: Micromanagement, poor selection of leadership,constant managerial change, poor work/life balance.  Would not recommend!

pros: Two personal holidays per year, one paid volunteer day per year, good IT department, comparable pay, diverse cultures, Go365, remote option
cons: Benefits could be a little better, a lot of micromanaging, past layoffs, “big brother” always watching,  switching from salary to hourly and being watched down to the minute

pros: Great benefits (medical, dental, vision, 401k, tuition reimbursement), Work at home opportunities, growth opportunities. Some members of management are incredible mentors
cons: You will be underpaid by industry standards and at times overworked. Change is the keyword in this environment and it is constant. Use the benefits, like tuition reimbursement, to offset the low pay. Some members of management are a bit overzealous and micromanage.

job_title: Computer Hardware Specialist in Tempe, AZ
pros: The other employees are great and they do little things like bring around treats to try and keep up moral. It pays the bills and the first year wasn't so bad.
cons: The work is terrible and grueling. After several years I am miserable and would do anything to get out. There is no advancing in position/pay. You are a working bee with no momentum. I get yelled at a lot by people on the phone when I'm doing everything I can to help.

review_title: Humana is stodgy and old fashioned
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Louisville, KY
pros: Learning opportunities, stable company, smart people.  The company is acquiring more providers of health services, and seems genuine in its goals of improving patient quality.
cons: HR is hypocritical: do as I say, not as I do.  This extends to their approach to performance reviews to compensation/promotions to policies like work at home.  Very smart employees, but many are very arrogant too.

pros: They have decent coverage for their employees and good PTO plan
cons: The upper hand doesnt have a clue what is to work a typical day in the trenches with the troops. They are coming up with new programs and incentivities and when we speak up to say they arent working no one listens or cares. I dont think upper management has ever spent a day answering the phones or even listening.

review_title: Great company in a complex industry
job_title: Internal Audit Senior Consultant in Louisville, KY
pros: High employee engagement and mobility, ability to work across functional areas, very competitive pay, chance to make a real difference in people's lives, very strong/visionary senior leadership team charting the course.
cons: Large company with multiple silos and technology platforms that make it difficult to get the "big picture."  Too much focus on maintaining relationships seems to entrench the status quo, rather than innovating to drive results.  Like any other large corporation, most managers/leaders are in back-to-back-to-back meetings.

review_title: Nightmare company-management is the worst ever
pros: They are always hiring but the pay sucks  fast turn over of staff
cons: The Guidance Centers managers are poor management-back stabbing cut throat liars that have terrible values and morals.They tell you they are supporting you but they dont they destroy you. Upper management has no life and it is reflected in their work. If they decided they dont like you they will conive and make up anything to get you fired, Dont even think of calling HR4U its a joke-dont even apply to this company its all smoke and mirrors.

job_title: TeleSale Miramar (Direct Market Sales, Phone) in Miramar, FL
pros: Decent salary, good people to work with, good opportunities for overtime when busy.  Good company if you just want to settle.
cons: No room for advancement.   Unfair way of distributing leads to employees.  Horrible benefits with very high deductibles.  Management are a bunch of idiots who are reactive rather than proactive who only look good because of driven employees.

pros: Pay.  Advancement for those with the right outlook and level of initiative.  Training available for other roles and growth.  Growing quickly so lots of opportunities for new jobs.   Good culture, really tries to keep staff happy and healthy.  New CEO is awesome.
cons: Tech playing catch up and IT sometimes drags feet.  Health coverage should be better.  Holds on to poor performers too long.

pros: Flexible, lots of growth, great benefits - lots of great people and training and much to learn in system integration projects
cons: Depending on management, it can be difficult to move up in the area you are in therefore you have to move to a completely different area to grow.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Westmont, IL
pros: Patient care and cost is priority. They keep their employees informed . They offer job advancement and exercise equality. They CARE !
cons: They have dual job descriptions that can change spontaneously .  They computer programs  are frequently unavailable making it difficulty to do your job in a timely manner. Most positions you can't work from home.

review_title: Good enough to stick it out (for now)
pros: I have worked for Humana for nearly eight years and feel secure in my job.  I have had the opportunity to grow and learn new and different skill sets that are interesting and challenging
cons: My job roles have changed tremendously year to year through "role expansions" though my compensation doesn't match my talent

pros: The culture is absolutely amazing and Humana really cares about their employees. They offer good benefits and help their employees and customers strive for good health and wellbeing.
cons: Depending on the department you work in, some are more stressful than others. I haven't personally had any bad experiences but I have heard from other departments that are a bit more stressful.

pros: The Company has good benefits and the opportunity to work from home.
cons: The culture has changed dramatically and the management is pushing numbers and not quality. They have reorganized the Humana at Home area several times in the last year and it has been detrimental to moral. The St. Petersburg branch has a disconnect from the main office in Louisville and their values are not the same. They have eliminated centralized training and the employees are left hanging.

pros: Other staff HCM  were supportive.
cons: I felt micromanaged and working from home was not a "privilege, but I felt more like a prisoner in my own home. The demands were insane, no breaks, and you the hours ended up longer 10 or more to make numbers. You had to call 10 successful calls per day. We weren't nurse educators, we were telemarketers. Very dissatisfied with this job and company who promised we were all "safe" but layoffs were coming.

job_title: Business Technology Consultant in Louisville, KY
pros:
- lots of room for growth
- excellent compensation packages, including 401k and vacation policy
- company goals are inspiring to individuals (help members achieve lifelong well-being, 20% healthier by 2020, etc.)
cons:
- big corporation can be tough to navigate
- most teams have a top-down, command-and-control culture, though there's a lot of effort to change this toward a more collaborative, innovative culture overall

job_title: RN Case Manager in Asheville, NC
pros: I worked for Humana for 5 years and found it to be a 'employee friendly' company.  They are passionate about helping the members and associates live healthy active lives.  There is also a big focus on community involvement and volunteerism.
cons: I was part of a work force reduction and would have liked to have been able to find another job within the organization, but most jobs posted ended up being filled by outside applicants-even though associates with outstanding job performance we're being let go.

review_title: Great place to work, great benefits
job_title: Provider Contract Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: Great benefits, work life balance, opportunities galore, great compensation package, often cash bonuses.
cons: Little negotiation with salaries, specially if growing from within.

pros: Good work-life balance, plenty of paid time off and holidays. There is opportunity to have employer paid development training and tuition reimbursement. Company culture was very pleasant and the management genuinely seemed to care for their employees well-being.
cons: Opportunity to move up in the company seemed to be contingent on who you knew.

pros: Good company, Strong leadership and values, diversity is paramount, moving in the right direction.  I am proud to be working at Humana.
cons: The compensation package could be slightly more competitive for the amount of work one puts into the job.  Other than that I don't have anything to complain about.

job_title: Customer Care Specialist in Louisville, KY
pros: Working from home, working for a wonderful company.  Heard a lot of good things from different people
cons: At this time I have no cons , everything went a lot easier than I thought, interview wise.

pros: The culture and values of the company keep  me loving what I do.
cons: Pay and salary increases are not motivating.  Very little recognition has been given to the work and added responsibilities of our team.   In the beginning I felt like my career and growth took 20 steps ahead but over the last year, it seems like I have taken 15 steps back which is really discouraging and frustrating.  A lot of this is out of my control which makes it worse.

job_title: Business Project Manager in Louisville, KY
pros: Interesting Work, Steady Work, Learning Environment, Pay, Tuition Reimbursement, Building Facilities and opportunities to work at home or work mobile.
cons: Salary Review Process that is done yearly.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Green Bay, WI
pros: Work from home is all
cons:
Management is forcing nurses to quit since about last December.
Humana is eliminating 250,000 plans
They took away our flex staffing and got rid of our managers and replaced them with stepford wives types... Not leaders...automatons...
They are writing elveryone up and making defamatory accusations to get nurses to resign ... 
Even writing up our military nurses... writing them up for excessive absenses after deployment???!!! Shame on You...
And yes I have documentation and names for all of my allegations.

pros: Good PTO, 401k match, like my immediate management, interesting work.
cons: Communication between departments is difficult. Little opportunity for advancement and unfair promotion practices. Raises are scarce and small, no cost of living increases and have to wait for performance increases. Peak periods can require a lot of night and weekend work.

pros: Large company, lots of opportunities to move around and advance. Good time off and retirement match. Good corporate culture of focusing on health and well-being.
cons: Unhealthy culture in some departments, relatively high-cost (high-deductible) medical insurance, unreasonable caps on raises make it difficult to increase salary via internal promotion. Board and senior execs currently more focused on selling the company than building the business or investing in employees.

pros:
Great place to learn how all Healthcare is done.
A lot of opportunity to learn how to use different tools

Great place for work and family balance

Good salaries if you know how to negotiate at the beginning of your start
cons:
Can get stuck in a department too long

Healthcare benefits thought it would be better working for insurance company

Not very big salary increases once you're in the company

pros: Humana has a great benefit package.  Working schedule is often flexible.
cons: The workloads are not distributed equally among employees.  The more you know, the more works you have at Humana.   Salaries are not paid fairly.  Many people are taking advantages of flexible hours.  There are too many project managers who lack of technical skills.

review_title: No Accountability from Senior Management...they'd rather bully their employees than provide the right tools for success.
pros: There are some really good people at Humana.
cons: Humana looks inwardly instead of looking at their customers. They spend countless hours in meetings and conference calls amongst themselves to reach decisions that could/should be made easily.  All decisions are bottom line based.   It's a bully culture.  High turnover reflects employee dis-satisfaction.

pros: Good salary, great PTO policy, good holidays, great tution, covers CEU's. Very generous with time off- I have been there 3 years- and have had Christmas break off every year. Front line leaders and directors very supportive of school.
cons: There is nothing I can say that is bad. I have been there 3 years- and it has pretty much all been positive.

pros: Decent pay, great coworkers, good incentives, room for growth.  Competitive products, great company direction.
cons: Management is not in tune with the real daily operations. Clients feel we are hard to do business with.  Fragmented and unpolished marketing.  Lots of higher up entrenched employees with no real value.

review_title: great place to start out - not much of a long-term prospect
pros: like many other reviewers mention, the work-at-home opportunities are excellent.   management in my dept does make a point to recognize work that goes above and beyond with public praise and small gestures of appreciation.
cons: advancement really only happens when you're well-connected and are in the good graces of the right manager at the moment.

job_title: Applications Consultant in Green Bay, WI
pros:
1. Great work culture
2. Invests in employee well being
3. 125% contribution in 401K
4. Flexible timings and work from home policy
cons:
1. Taken over by Aetna created uncertainty 
2. Struggling in commercial side of the business due to high administration cost
3. Overall healthcare industry is impacted by 20% profit cap

pros: Awesome company. I have worked many places but working at Humana you can tell that the company really cares for the people that work for them.
cons: There are not many downsides to Humana. The payroll department could be a little more professional when it comes to making sure people's pay is right. Other than that no complaints.

pros: Humana is a great place for growth. The company has programs, classes, etc. catered to the personal growth of their emplyees.
cons: Humana has a culter of its own, so it may be hard to adjust if going to another company or for someone who is comeing to Humana from another company.

job_title: Senior Quality Assuramce in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Company us easy to work for. Does good at promoting from within
cons: Center mood depends  on upper managment mood.   One must really get in good with management or you will not go anywhere.  To many favorites. Who get special treatment. Rules dont apply to everyone

review_title: Worst company I've ever worked for.
pros: None I can think of. It's a paycheck, that's it.
cons: Mandatory overtime with little to no notice. NEVER any rewards for work well done. The only ones that receive any kind of rewards are management; also little praise for work well done. Almost constant criticism, and demands, a very regimented, structured place to work. Constant, almost daily change. Their 401K is good but no better than any other company I've ever worked for.

review_title: Management Not Great. When you speak up your put on Performance Improvement Plan.
pros: Many good benefits: tuition reimbursement, low premiums for insurance. Certain jobs off flex schedule. Work from home options.
cons: Review system for advancement needs revamped. Pay differnece is Huge and should have a scale. Management isn't great. Should hire more from within when it comes to management. High Deductible insurance plans.

pros: Work from home is sometimes offered
cons:
Ever changing higher management. Lack of communication to normal employees. Raises are not even worth being called raises.  If you're a male, you'll be paid more even if you don't do your job. They take advantage of the workers who work hard and don't acknowledge that they've done well.  "Party manager" is horrible at her job but no one can say anything about it or risk being fired.
Your health benefits are horrid. Be better just buying your own.

review_title: Act like a stereotypical big company
pros:
Best pay and benefits in the region
Relatively easy to move around in the company
cons:
-Moving around the company is mandatory if you want a raise more than 1%
-85% of learning is on the job training
-going through extensive layoffs despite beating analyst projections shows how loyal management is to workers

review_title: 2 years experience in telephonic care management
pros: Work from home and the company and coach have been very flexible about appointments or family concerns and have no issues with taking time off
cons: Worry of job security constantly with layoffs all the time. Being told multiple ways of doing our jobs while we are feeling as if we are constantly being monitored

job_title: Customer Care Representatives in Tempe, AZ
pros: benefits, that's about it.  But high deductible plans, not the  best plans.
cons: Most micromanaged job you'll ever have,  worst managers you'll ever have.  Just don't have to go to the bathroom and you'll be ok, but if you do they micromanage that as well.  Many unethical practices like changing your scores that they give you raises on so you can't rebutt them if they don't concern you.  you have to ave 96% on qaulity or they fire you.   Long hours back to back with no breaks, if your not on the phone they are chatting or harrassing you.   Skip this job!!!

pros: Humana is a great place to work in terms of the overall experience you can gain, the people you meet, and the potential for growth.
cons: It is wise to choose the department that you work for very carefully. It is good to get your foot in the door, learn the departments and see which one you could do best in.

review_title: Extremely political, good old boys club
pros: Great pay but at the cost of any family time.
cons: The company is setup to promote those who just going along without trying to do the right thing.  Hard work is not rewarded.  Your contributions don't matter ; just stay off the radar and you'll do well. The HR department is the company's  own worst enemy.  It's disjointed, out dated and apathetic.

job_title: IT Program Manager in Louisville, KY
pros: Good pay, good work is often recognized, lots of opportunity for growth and advancement if you are good. Work at home opportunity for some positions, company is very supportive.
cons: Pace is FAST - you have to be a go-getter and handle stress, deadlines well.  Learning curve to navigate in large company is long.  Healthcare benefits have high deductibles, but that is everywhere these days.

pros: They people are great. You have your own desk space. I love the cafeteria they have. There are always opening for moving up within the company. The supervisors and directors were all very friendly while I worked there. I made life long friends while working there also. There are so many options for someone to move up within the company.
cons: There was a lot of overtime during the companies open enrollment period but they tell you that before you get hired on.

pros: There is a great benefit to working from home. You have some flexibility and can make your own hours for the most part.
cons: The policy and procedures change often which can make it difficult to stay on track without someone telling you are doing something wrong because you didn't realize that the policy changed. there is also very little judgement left to the care manager which feels like you are constantly being under minded.

pros: Humana is a large company which provides stability, although they were recently purchased by another large company.   They are concerned about employees' health and well-being.
cons:
The fact they are large means many layers of management.
For such a large company involved in health insurance, their technology is not as good as it should be.
They waste a lot of time in non-productive activities to promote employees' health and well-being.

pros: Compensation is decent for the market.  People you work with directly are usually easy to get along with.
cons: Tends to be way too many projects and tasks going on for anyone to be able to complete them all successfully.  It's too easy for a few individuals who don't understand something to stop it.

pros: They tried to acknowledge loyalty and longevity with gifts and service award plaques. They tried to keep associates in remote offices informed with quarterly webinars and calls hosted by senior leadership.
cons: Its a huge company so there was a lot of bureaucracy and inefficient processes. There wasn't a lot of explanation as to why things would be done in a certain way. There was a disconnect between the vision and the execution.

pros: The PTO accrual is generous, decent pay. Work from home possibilities
cons: Because of the high volume of calls and high demands from management and QA it creates a stressful work environment. Too many metrics that prohibits the rep from providing an A-1 experience for the members.

job_title: Personal Health Coach (PHC) in Cincinnati, OH
pros: Pay, tuition reimbursement, benefits are expensive. Overall, with recent events and being laid off my view of Humana has changed. Disappointed!
cons: They sell you a dream coming in the door...micromanage, micromanage. No transparency during lay these lay offs. Cold and flat in telling employees and very nonchalant upper management. Humana at home is a joke ! Expectations are unreal...no consistency with Job duties.

pros: Work at home options. Basic ladder climbing structure.
cons: Evidence of typical corporate insurance double talk- many dissatisfied consumers, limited ability to connect them to services that will actually help. Overworked employees for middle-of-the-road income, often performing multiple roles at the same time due to staff shortages. Recent layoffs and instability of career paths.

review_title: Your leader makes all the difference
job_title: Senior BI Engineer in Louisville, KY
pros: Decent pay and benefits.  Decent opportunities for growth and advancements.  Your career is in your hands.
cons: Homegrown talents are slow to reach industry norms for pay with experience.  Your individual leader makes all the difference in the environment in which you work.  Constant hiring freezes as we try and force doing more with less

pros:
Great benefits esp health and dental
Good people
Majority of my work was from 8:30 - 5.  It helped with my work life balance.
Other MSA are pretty good to work with
cons:
Pay is below average
Upper management did not addess some of the negative work conditions.
There is nepotism within the upper management ranks in addition to a pretty strond old boys club that can hard to get into. Knowledge of golf and sports help alot.

pros: Decent pay. Healthcare reform may bring even better pay.

pros:
- Humana is a very employee-centric company.
- Decent benefits with exception to health insurance.
cons:
-Very hard to break into director or above level positions unless you come into the company at director level.
-Very silo'd company.  
-Biz area segment not necessarily aligned for efficiency.
-Concerned about the number of C-level execs that have been hired w/o healthcare background
-Needs better insurance options

pros: If you have a reasonable supervisor, this can be a great job.
cons: I recently resigned from Humana because of what may be the worst boss in America. The job is intended to be a good balance between work and home but this boss tracked every second of the day. Her management style was akin to that of Joseph Stalin. I attempted to work with her on her style but it only angered her and created even greater resentment which in return was met with greater micro management, constant criticism and bullying. Humana can be a great place to work but be sure you are getting a good boss.

review_title: Best company I have ever worked for!
job_title: Dental Claims Specialist in De Pere, WI
pros: Endless room for professional growth. Amazing benefits - medical, dental, 401k. Company inspires well-being. Flexible hours. Work at home. Great pay and generous vacation hours.
cons: There are no cons to working at Humana. I have nothing but positive things to say. I would recommend Humana as an employer to family and friends.

review_title: Great company to work for.  I really enjoy this company.  It is a great place to work and has a good culture.
pros: Nice people.  Tons of opportunity.  Forward thinking.  A great place to learn to grow and become more skilled and marketable in your chosen field.
cons: I have no real complaints, but I am not one to endlessly complain about things.  If you are in a customer service oriented area I'm sure things are different, but in the professional world things run smoothly.

pros: Fast paced company.  Advancement opportunities are offered to thise who show the initiative and work ethic, not just a carrot at the end of a stick like most employers in this industry
cons: Complacency is common. Working with other whom dont appear to have the qualifications for their responsibilities is common. Having to deal with these people is a day to day struggle.

pros: The people are incredible - smart, talented and more than happy to help and provide advice and guidance. Love the culture and focus on well-being, development, and associate and member experience. I work for a leader that empowers me to speak up, create ideas and implement.
cons: There is always more work to do and more that can be done, many times without enough people to support all we want to be able to do for our members.

review_title: It is a great company to work for.
job_title: Registered Nurse Case Manager in Newport News, VA

pros: Pay is pretty good considering that I work from home.

I've worked in three separate departments and been treated as if I'm an ignorant child at 35 years old. If you are a woman, be prepared to be pushed down.  Men are rare and so far have been delightful to work with.

review_title: Great pay, hard work and favortism, can you handle it?

Job stability is non-existent.

review_title: It's fine to start out there

job_title: Health Care Coordinator in Glen Allen, VA

cons: Too much emphasis on quantity and care plans that have to be perfect and are reviewed by quality review folks who ding you for just one typo. This has caused a lot of work stress.

pros: Good location in dallas texas, has decent hourly wage, the lifesync behavioral health was a good trainer, explaned everything well and made surs you understood.
cons: Too much corporate back stabing. The leads in the dallas location judge by how you dress. In traing you have to dummy yourself down when you have a medical background, do not participate or answer any queistions because the trainer is insecure. Watch your back.

pros: Humana offers a wealth of opportunity for growth and wonderful benefits for their associates.  Here are often opportunities for advancement or lateral movement.
cons: Humana often has reorganization which results in job loss.  They do try to find placement within for displaced workers.  Some are able to stay for long careers at Humana, but you never know when focus will change.

review_title: Unreasonable write ups. Actually fired due to outsourcing and/or budget cuts.
pros: Great pay. Work from home. Flex schedule.
cons:
There is no benefit to working hard. Promotions are not based on performance. Mass hiring and mass layoffs are a yearly occurrence. Organizational structure is in constant flux resulting in a workforce who barely knows who they report to. 

Fired on 7 year anniversary. This happened literally 30 minutes after a department meeting where it as announced that 40 new associates in Puerto Rico will be hired on. Termination reasons were true at surface level, but dont tell the full story. 

Fired for: 
-Not responding to an email within 24 hours. Which email? one of the 15 sent daily of which it is unclear whether or not a response is required?

-Missed production this month. First time in 7 years missing production. Production was only missed because I was working right from a work list provided by management. In fact, this was the first month I said to heck with my own way or doing things and worked strictly from the list they provided. 

-Idle time too high. I do agree idle time is high, but no matter how consistently work is getting done idle time is always over their expectation. The idle time counter is ill understood by management and is micromanagement at its finest. How can idle time be 3 hours a day, yet production goals are far exceeded? Hours worked are more important than work done. 

-Case out of compliance. An aged case was found nearing the compliance deadline. Email was sent to management about said case. Management said they would take care of it. This was all documented via email. Case was not taken care of by management. The case eventually aged out of compliance and resulted in a write up. 

After 7 years of service and never missing a performance bonus or a day of work, there was no acknowledgement of the good. Only mention of the final month where  new systems are creating chaos within the department and mistakes were being made.

pros: Good pay; decent benefits; nice cafeteria. Nice view of the water. Covered parking, close to the main buiding. Some of the coworkers were nice.
cons:
Told I was going to do .NET development. I did two years of classic ASP, not by choice, I was forced to. At the time ratio of managers to developers was close to 50/50. I lost two years of my life. 
Make sure you are not going to be another victim of a Bait-and-switch.

review_title: So far, I've had a great experience with Humana
pros: The best  reason to work for Humana is you have no fair of lay off, and the pay is good.
cons: The Tampa office is made up of clicks, and if you are not part of the click, opportunities are not given to you.

pros: This is the best place to work. Company really helps you grow, teache you, provide essential or required training, recognizes your talent and definitely hard work and rewards you for hard work. Humana is the best place to work if you want stability in career. Proud to work for humana. And lucky also ;)
cons: No cons ... This company has no cons

review_title: Great Company to work for.to get experience in Healthcare field.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Miramar, FL

cons: The environment is stressfull,management likes to micromanage and to get promoted is very difficult they don't know how to manage talent and experience is not a factor for getting promoted.

pros: Very employee friendly, consumer centered, wellness minded company! Great PTO policy (3 weeks), 125% 401k match, and above average pay. Very well run company...upper management has positioned the company for long term success, even with the changes in the healthcare industry.
cons: Can be political, however, no more than any other big company.

pros: Generous PTO time and no problems getting time off when requested.  Ability to work from home and flexibility with your schedule

pros: The people at Humana definitely make the job worthwhile. The passion is evident and built within their caring, progressive culture. Coming to work each day is exciting, not a burden.

review_title: As a whole, Humana is a great company to work for.

review_title: Clinical Services has gone extremely downhill.  I’m a Pharmacist trying to leave!
pros: Work from home option, bonus
cons: Excessive overtime due to seemingly poor staffing levels, inadequate pay raises (seem to decrease every year), limited vacation options, increased expectations, and a culture that seems to encourage ratting out other pharmacists instead of working together and fixing problems.  Things keep getting worse year to year and management can’t or won’t protect us in a way that I had come to expect from my history with the company.

review_title: Not a bad place to work at all, people just need to think outside their box.

pros: My fellow co-workers. The individuals that  I refer to as  my extended family, perform extraordinary feats on a daily basis with one goal in mind...servicing the members! No matter the amount of negative energy pushed their way from management and a small host of members. They trudge forward.
cons: Job Stagnation!  At this juncture of a two year transition to a wellness company, career progression is non-existent unless your goals are in the mail order Rx business.

review_title: Humana is a great place to work
pros: Humana is very focused on their employees and their customers and work to create the best environments to improve the experiences of both. It is nice to know that a company of this size still has the right priorities.

pros: Management expresses genuine interest in your success.  It's a great work environment and an excellent opportunity to learn from some of the best in the industry.

review_title: Over 40 and highly paid - Seek other employment
pros: There are a large number of very nice people in the company.  Salaries are competitive.  The company is large enough that you can find another position if you are unhappy with your leadership.
cons:
The reason Humana has so many job openings is because they right-size every year between Sept. and Dec.  This avoids paying MIP bonuses and reduces the long term debt that needs to be reported to stockholders.  If you are not a director, but are over 40 and highly paid, it is likely to be you.  Several years ago, I helped coach an associate who was over 40 and was given a severance of 1 month salary and told they were doing a bad job.  With the letter was a printout of something called the "Over 40 List" that showed by role how many people who received such a "package"  were in different age groups.  Only one was under 40.  (This list is no longer in the packets.)  In the past, your management saw the paperwork about why you needed to be on medical leave or FMLA before it was sent to HR.  Poor health also makes you a target .  If you doubt this, look around at those who are right-sized and note how many are over 40 and how many more women are released than men - their health care costs are higher.  Humana used to let everyone go on Fridays and usually at the end of the month.  Having gotten smarter, now people are let go every day between Sept and Dec.  This makes it almost impossible to file a class action lawsuit since all must file within 180 days for age discrimination.

As other have stated, the health insurance is pitiful.  One year,  employee's renewals were changed to July so Humana could get feedback on he new benefit packages and software before delivering it to clients.  This also allowed Humana to charge higher rates to employees for 6 months.

Much of Humana's leadership is autocratic and extremely political.  Many of those receiving poor "engagement scores" were given an associate who's primary role is to keep associates happy and get those scores up.  Humana promotes many young talented people, but their salary increase for the promotion is minimal.  This creates a situation where many of their associates make considerably more money than the manager.  There is little management training before and after promotion and the lack of experience, arrogance and resentment makes associates over 40 a prime target when the just-in-time appraisals are done to target those who will be terminated.

The outsourcers who handle long and short term disability have one mission, get your disability disapproved or get you back to work as soon as possible.  They ignore your doctor's written statement that you are not ready to g back to work and harass those who are actually ill.

Humana used to offer bonuses to managers but most of these have been eliminated.  Salary increases are also higher for directors and above.  This makes a huge variance between leadership and individual contributors or middle management.

pros: Really into Associate engagement, work life balance, wellness, etc.   Great company!
cons: Be prepared to speak "business-ease"  words like "business acumen" and "collaboration"  etc.    I am so ready for businesses to just speak normal!

review_title: It is almost the only game in town
pros:
Overall, if you value 9-5, it's great for getting home predictably. The company is very concerned with keeping member data protected. Customer service from the customer service representatives is a fundamental "must have". You may not get the answer you want or like to hear, but you will be treated with respect, politeness, and a desire to resolve your problem or issue within the defines of your plan.

Salary is higher than average FOR THE AREA. 
401k match is excellent.
cons:
1) Bureaucracy is rampant. Upper management wants front-line workers to be invisible. Do not make any waves and you will do okay. (Precisely okay)
2) Focus is on money and not quality of work. Shoddy work is "good enough" or okay.
3) Anything you say or type can and will be used against you. 
4) Antiquated software tools used to run IT. Some of the tools are no longer supported by the developer, while others are about to join the living dead (software).
5) Cross team collaboration is minimal and invariably a pain point.
6) If something seems rational to expect, expectations will not be met.
7) Middle management spends vast amount of time protecting their job, not yours.
8) The Louisville area pays below the national average for IT positions even when adjusted for cost of living. Unless you are manager, director, or higher there is ZERO incentive or performance recognition pay. No bonuses. No stock. Nada.
9) Limited opportunities for promotion. There is little differentiation within a position to move from a junior xxx to a senior xxx since the junior, senior, or number do not exist. Promotion means change in responsibilities vs. acknowledgement of higher level of performance and competence.
10) Despite being a health insurance company, the offerings to the employees is arguably almost as bad as it can be while still having insurance. Hourly employees would have to "contribute" 1/2 of their take-home pay to have mediocre coverage for their whole family.
11) Anything that can be done to save a buck in the short-term is done. Something like requesting a "different" mouse requires 2 levels of manager approvals before the request can be submitted to purchasing.

review_title: Good resume builder, horrible for career
pros:
If you are smart enough to negotiate a high salary in the beginning, you can make out pretty well.  

Many locations nationwide.

Multitude of departments means there is often a job out there you will fit into.
cons:
Pay raises are based on a percentage, which actually puts those that start their career there at a disadvantage compared to those that come in from other companies.

Performance reviews have no bearing on pay increase, advancement opportunity, or anything of significance.  They are pretty much just a pat on the back or a request to do something better.

Very political. If you meet the right people and do your best to woo them, you'll do well.  However, if you prefer to be rewarded for performance and dedication to your job, you will be extremely disappointed.

Lack of communication from management. Everyone below management level is on a need-to-know basis...bordering on deception.

Benefits are mediocre at best. As an employee you are the guinea pig for the company; especially in regard to your health coverage. Now you only have a choice between various levels of high deductible health plans. Meanwhile, in the same market, PPO's and sometimes even HMO's are offered. 

Sleepless nights. If you want to work in healthcare to help people, avoid the private payer. All decisions ultimately come down to the bottom line impact. It has a very dehumanizing effect.

You will be solicited to contribute to charities, Political Action Committees (PAC), or any other program that has little benefit to you unless you have vested interest.

review_title: Do not work for this company.  So wasteful and most people are willing to step on whoever to get where they want.

review_title: An easily hateable place to waste 40+ hours each week.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in De Pere, WI
pros:
- Above average salary.
- Generous tuition reimbursement.
- We have a pond out back. That's kind of neat.
cons:
Here's a perfect example of how this place works. If you're in a meeting room and you don't like the temperature, you can't touch the thermostat in the room. In short, De Pere has to call Louisville who calls a different De Pere number to handle climate control.

Benefits are garbage. The health insurance offers next to no coverage unless you shell out several thousand dollars first. Premiums are way over inflated for the coverage you get. Any kind of customer service position will see virtually every member has better coverage than they do and may pay less for it.

Politics are horrible. If your supervisor does not like you, they will look for a reason to ride you out of there. I have seen this countless times with tenured employees.

I was randomly pulled into a room with management and grilled regarding a personal matter that required time away from work. I was initially told the time away was fine, but then someone in upper management decided it was not. I was threatened over the course of two weeks regarding this while an inappropriate level of personal information was requested by management to "investigate" my issue. Ended up with a write up over something I was initially told was fine.

You'll routinely be asked to learn new skills, complete additional training, and have a heightened skillset once you're there for a while. The more I took on, the less flexibility I had. I could never adjust my schedule when the opportunity came up. PTO was now HARDER to use because only 1 person with my skillset could have the day off. It's a sucker's move to do more than the bare minimum job function. 

Don't ever get sick. I became very ill during my initial training period. My trainer contacted her manager and they agreed to let me leave early for the day. I did not request this. When I returned to work, I was told that because this was a day before a holiday that they would not be paying me for that time. I fought to no avail with the supervisor. When I told my trainer about this, luckily she was able to fight for me and I did get that time paid. Having to provide an EOB from my doctor was ridiculous. And, like I said, they sent me home -- and then tried to punish me for it!

Family member has a serious health condition. I applied for FMLA through their third party company Unum. After taking some time, I get a letter in the mail that they're revoking my leave because of a "pattern" of absences. They enclose paperwork to give to my doctor for my serious health condition....even though I'm obviously not the ill one. I have to fight (including a shouting match with an outsourced nightmare of a human being) because a specific date was not included for one phase of treatment and this treatment was weeks at a time. It was literally the equivalent of a t not being crossed, but they didn't hesitate to rake me over the coals for it.

I'm not the only one that has had a problem with these vultures. A co-worker with a deteriorating heart condition was threatened over an absence where their supervisor had to call an ambulance. This co-worker also got FMLA time, but was routinely interrogated over absences as the condition got worse.

Another co-worker flat out gave up trying to get time approved for their child's condition. 

HR is a waste of time. I had the same supervisor for a year. When I was eligible to apply for other positions in different departments, I did not hesitate. Through the interview process, I found out my supervisor was speaking ill of me to one of the hiring managers that she was close friends with. After more than a year of being barked at and blatantly treated differently (as point out by several co-workers) I attempted to contact HR to report unprofessional treatment. 

Three days after filing my initial complaint, I received a call from a guy and he immediately dismissed me. He told me we had "personality conflicts" and they didn't get in the middle of those. I had several pages of notes and willing co-workers to speak on my behalf on the treatment I received compared to others. Didn't matter. They did offer to speak to my supervisor, but then point blank told me this would all but ruin any chance of me getting an offer in a different department. Retaliation, much?

Threats. You're always doing something wrong. Dress code is always a big one. A co worker wore a themed shirt for breast cancer during our breast cancer awareness week. She was threatened with discipline because the shirt had a hood on it -- but was not a "hoodie."

Management decided to resurface the parking lot. Employees were forced to park in the fields and gravel areas surrounding the building. We received a nasty email from the VP onsite telling us there is PLENTY of parking and anyone parking in a "non paved" area would be towed! Yes, they closed a large portion of the parking lot and then threatened to tow people that had no choice but to park in the mud.

pros: Humana is a wonderful employer.  Associates are encouraged multiple times daily to take care of their wellness.  There are onsite fittness centers with classes and personal trainers.  Humana also encourages career development.  There are a variety of resources to help associates grow.
cons: Management is sometimes disorganized and some parts of the company often are out of the loop when it comes to opportunities and certain benefits.

review_title: The Tampa MSOP is management by favoritism, tattling, and it's a racist environment.
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tampa, FL
pros: Pay was decent. PTO was accrued at a decent rate, just couldn't get it approved.
cons: Back-stabbing, racist, couldn't get PTO approved, the term "team" is a joke, definitely favored employees get preferential treatment. The systems don't interact. For an insurance company the employee insurance plans were terrible.

review_title: Overall, Humana has been a decent company. Depending on which work group or classification and if you began w/ a merger
pros: At times, you can make your schedule "work for you" , depending on your position
cons: Wit Humana, depending on the group you began with, it can take a while for a promotion or deserving raise. Merges seem promising, but uncertain. A little shaky at times.

review_title: Too strict...feels like I'm back home with my parents
pros: Good benefits and pays ok.
cons: Constant watching over employees like children. It's almost like spying. Better not leave one minute prior to your work hours are over. Very punitive environment and culture.

job_title: RN Case Manager in Tampa, FL
pros: My supervisor, had empathy, but unable to help with the amount of workload.
cons: Everything!  Do not work here unless you like to disappoint your patients.  I felt it was against my ethics to work here.  My patients would tell me that Humana sucked and what was I to say to them but "I agree".  They company makes it very hard for patients.  Meanwhile they are redoing their corporate offices in marble.  Priorities are so wrong!  Corporate America at its finest!!

pros: Great people to work with. Good pay. Great benefits except the Medical Insurance
cons: For being an insurance company the medical was expensive and was not good. High Deductible plans only.

pros: Decent benefits available right away upon full-time status.
cons: Cares about members health, but not the employees. Tethered to phones all day with minimal breaks. Very micro managed.

job_title: Senior Actuarial Analyst in Louisville, KY
pros: Very Strong Actuarial Rotation Program.  The care about the growth of every student.  Great benefits including 22 day PTO that roles over.
cons: Location isn't the best given it's in louisville KY.  Given the Aetna merger, there is some concern about job security.

job_title: Community Health Educator in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Very few. I've stuck around for the tuition reimbursement while I'm completing my master's degree. if I could find another job that offered a comparable amount ($5000/year), I would be out the door as fast as I could. I've had worse health insurance (but that doesn't say much when you're working for a health insurance company).
cons:
Where do I start? Upper management continues to push productivity expectations to impossible heights. Leaders are completely out of touch with what most member-facing associates experience everyday, even though we voice our concerns - repeatedly. Management insists we must increase "quantity" while simultaneously improving "quality".

Management refuses to admit that higher productivity standards result in low-quality, corner-cutting interactions with members. It’s all about your performance metrics - unfortunately the metrics are not built well enough to capture your work. Corporate arrogance reigns in thinking members benefit from being called multiple times a month (in my opinion the number of calls we make to members amounts to harassment).

Middle management is stuck drinking upper management’s kool-aid and regurgitating it to member-facing associates. If you are an intelligent individual who speaks out when something is a-miss, you will never be hired or promoted to a manager position within the company. Independent thinkers need not apply. To become a manager you have to know the right people, and either keep your suggestions for company improvement to yourself or be completely ignorant to the corruption within.

Since the acquisition by Aetna was announced (at 2am, on a holiday weekend, in an email to employees - this says it all!) things have gotten progressively more hostile. Nearly 40 employees in a specific position were informed in a company-wide email that if they did not have a master's degree, they would no longer be able to hold their current position. They've been told they can *try* to find a different position within the company (which pays significantly less) or accept severance. It's a crummy way to treat people, but this company does not see its associates as people, only money-making vessels.

The fact that this company preaches well-being is a joke. They stress their employees to the point of burnout, and then expect us to "engage" in the company. Guess what? We don't have time to engage because of the workload....and most of us aren't really buying that you give a hoot about our well-being. High deductible health plans, reducing 401k employer matching and other well-being rewards aren't sending that message.

From reading other reviews, it seems like some departments of the company are better than others to work for. Humana At Home has not been a pleasant experience for me. I bought in to the company "values" and worked my butt off for the first year, wondering why most co-workers who had been there longer were so apathetic. Now I know. I have seen many new employees come into the company with the same optimistic and hard-working attitude that I had, only to crash and burn a year later. It's sad, really. This company does not practice what it preaches.

pros: Humana is a great company that really values its employees.  They offer a ton of benefits to show their appreciation.
cons: Sometimes you can feel distant from other associates, expecially if you work from home.  Humana is always trying new things to try and improve associate engagement.

review_title: Stressful. Lack of quality management. Felt like I was working on an assembly line as a master's level employer.
pros: I initially enjoyed the work with the medicare population but shortly came to find the requirements for calls per day unacceptable.
cons: Very stressful. No room for movement. Lack of concern for employee welfare

-

review_title: A great company to grow professionally
pros: I worked for Humana for 5 years, and I enjoyed every minute of it.  It was my first corporate job and I learned a lot during my time there. The direct leaders are extremely supportive, and help their employees grow professionally.
cons: The top leaders are only concerned with growing "the business". Which means associates that no longer fit into the vision become expendable.

review_title: No track for career growth, lots of uncertainty around the company following recent layoffs, political climate bad.

cons: Lack of diversity.  No clear path for career advancement.  To get a promotion or raise, you need to leave the company.  Some directors have no business being directors.

pros: Good Benefits, Work at Home positions for some

Promotions come as a result of seniortiy or popularity instead of skill set.   THere are many folks in upper management who don't understand Management priniciples.   Company operates with 1960's mentality.   Diversity in upper management is non existent,  Humana, get with the program
Poor leadership.

review_title: Long hours, boring work, no room for advancement.
pros: They offer a competitive pay and have a four day work week. Most of the people who work there are fun to be around.
cons: There is no room for advancement. They never give pay raises. Managers and leads think they are better than everyone else.

review_title: Salary is low compared to industry standard, but was an overall ok place to work

review_title: Over 40 and paid well BEWARE you are probably next to lose your job!
pros: Some wonderful people in the general workforce. Challenging career, great educational reimbursement, flexible schedule.  There are some very excellent workers there but it is overshadowed by poor middle management, and HR staff.
cons:
Middle management is allowed to openly disrespect their employees, it is okay for managers and supervisors to sit in meetings and openly discuss inappropriate topics at work, go out to bars and belittle their employees in front of other employees and upper management ignores it all.  Beware if your over 40 Humana has a long history of doing cuts during Sept and Dec for the over 40 crowd who are paid well. They do this during this time so that they can report less debt to their stock holders in year ending numbers. Far to many excellent employees who were considered subject matter experts where suddenly told they were terrible employees put on CCIP one month and gone the next with no coaching or guidance. They were basically set up to fail. Humana considers human beings administrative reductions nothing more. Teams are run like high school cliches if your supervisor does not like you then your going nowhere and eventually you will be fired regardless of your work quality. HR is even worse in GB they openly are friends with supervisors on FB and discuss personal opinions with supervisors at their desk for others to hear. Managers are allowed to openly publish threats on FB like mess with me and I will open a whole lot of ?!?!? on you and your family. This reflects extremely poor on a corporation overall.   
The term if you don't like it there's the door was said often to personnel who complained of to much work or stress. or Be thankful you have a job there are 50 people I can replace you with tomorrow was another favorite said to those that did not want to continue with the mandatory 10 hours of overtime for the 8 week in a row. 
Favoritism was huge some Specialist had 20 cases while others had 60 plus it all depended on if the manager or supervisor liked you or not. A lot of back stabbing and hurting others to climb the corporate ladder happens CYB was said on a daily basis.

pros: Plenty of opportunity to create a positive and productive culture
cons: Business Development group lead managed through fear, intimidation and fostered a lack of trust within the team.

job_title: Utilization Review RN in Dublin, OH
pros: The salary is decent, but is it really worth the grief that comes with it?  Not to me it is not.
cons: The management team in the East Central Region in Dublin, Ohio is terrible!  They will micromanage the most effective teams and nurses, leading to these nurses becoming disengaged and disgruntled.  I could list two specific nurses who saved the corporation more than $7 million and management has not so much as provided a pat on the back or thank you.  Instead, they are trying to push these two nurses out the door!  These two nurses have received a COMBINED pay raise of 5% over almost a 3 year period!  Their performance review system is the most absurd method I have ever seen demonstrated by any employer!  I am getting ready to exit the company to move on in a much higher and more prestigious position in the world of providing healthcare.  I cannot wait to leave this sad employer.  If you not a "yes" man/woman or looking to get your nose brown from kissing butt, I would suggest looking for employment with a different company.  Family does not come first with this company either.  Call in just one day with a perfect attendance record and they will jump all over you!  Very sad that management in Dublin, Ohio is selected by using the "good old boy" system.  It is all in who you know and has absolutely nothing to do with being actually qualified to step into the position of leading others.  The East Region in Louisville, KY is outstanding, but the East Central Region in Dublin, Ohio is terrible from the top down.  Do NOT waste your time applying to work there if you value your morals!

pros: I enjoy working for Humana. I work with a cohort of many other young, intelligent professionals who are eager to contribute to this company. Lots of opportunities for growth.
cons: Humana has said they are trying to end "silos" but from the sales end, that is all we see. Not enough fluidity.

cons: HR4U was great to help when needed questions asked but only during business hours. Benefits packages would be best described during orientation.

Working from home
